print_settings.Notes:: On the second magnet insertion, make sure you place them with the correct polarity or your box won't close.

description.text: My nephew loves games and puzzles, so I wanted to print him a set of the Tsugite Tangle blocks by Devin Montes over at My Mini Factory (files available here: https://www.myminifactory.com/object/tsugite-tangle-30821). But I wanted a box to put them in, so I designed this. There are recesses at about 7.5 mm and 43.5 mm to put magnets; I used 1/4" x 1/16" neodymium magnets. The box is designed to be printed in one piece without supports.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I passed my gcode through Prusa's color-print utility: http://www.prusaprinters.org/color-print/

I used 7.3 and 43.3 as the levels to add the M600 (Filament swap g-code), though you could probably do a couple of tenths higher. Assuming your printer supports the M600 g-code, the print should pause, the hotend will move away from the print area, and will unload your filament. It is at this point that you can insert the magnets. It's kind of a tight fit; I found the best way was to stick the magnet to a spatula and use that to push down into the recess. After your magnets are inserted, you'll need to reload your filament, and the print should resume right where you left off.

On the second magnet insertion, make sure you place them with the correct polarity or your box won't close.

description.text: The Big Sister from the BioShock series. I added a lot of detail to this model, so it should be reserved to print on machines capable of good resolution for best results. Please note that I have not printed this one yet, I tried to make everything within tolerance levels, but you can never be sure until you print it. So if anyone does, be sure to share! The original likeness of this character belongs to 2K Games, so don't go around selling this print commercially. UPDATE I went back and fixed a few issues with the model, it should print fine now. I also decimated the model from 2 million polys, down to 400,000 since most printers can't even attain the detail that was embedded in the model.
I had to use quite a few supports around the cage area. So please be smart about support placement.

title: JeSc Tevo Tarantula Layer Fan with 18mm sensor

description.text:
Made both fan ducts using http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1591912 by sobezuki, published May 27, 2016

And the 30-40 version I also used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1759396 by Galane, published Sep 8, 2016

I added an 18mm inductive sensor holder as an upgrade

Print both in ABS, because it is very close to the hot end and PLA will melt!

OFFSET SENSOR:
Y offset = 0
X offset = 40
Z offset = up to you ;)

Adjust Marlin firmware configuration.h (approx. line 604-605)
define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 40 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]

The 30-30 version needs as additional parts:
1x Cooling fans 30x30x10mm
4x Bolds m3x50

The 30-40 version needs as additional parts:
1x Cooling fan 40x40x10 or 40x40x20
4x Bolds m3x50 to attach fan duct
4x Bolds m3x20 or m3x30 to attach 40x40mm fan

description.text: This is an interior door handle for the sliding doors of an NV200 van that has been designed in Fusion 360. The handle attaches directly to two built in mounting points on the van via 8mm screws which are set 60mm off center. I have enclosed a Nissan cargo van interior diagram and this part fits into the holes marked "D" on the diagram. The handle has two 9mm holes and the mounting has been angled so the handle is easily accessible from the outside of the van. The same handle can be used for both left and right sides. I designed the part to be printed, flat on the bed, without support of any kind. I am printing triangle infill at 30% density to create a truss-like part interior. This is my second Fusion 360 project and I am very impressed with it.

I will soon be back with more battlefront characters and ships

For those DC fans out there, injustice models are coming!

title: ORD Bot Inspired Spool Carrier
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a spool carrier inspired by my ORD Bot.
It is adjustable to all the spools I could find.

You can print the feet from the attached STEP file.  The rest of the stuff you must scrounge or buy.
Use the STEP file or drawing to measure and cut the parts.
The rollers at the ends are standard electrical conduit with 5x16x5 bearing press fit into the ends.
The framing is 20mm x 20mm Misumi T-Slot extrusion.  You need to tap the center holes of the shorter cross members. 
You can adjust for most spool sizes by sliding in one of the ends.  You just need the spool to hang down below the frame a bit so the spool will never walk off the end.
By the way, ORD Bot kits are now on sale at Inventables.com!

comments.text: There are now printable lengths of T-Slot on Thingiverse as well.

title: 3D Printed Gumball Machine Repaired Using Wood Filler

description.text:
I printed a copy of this gumball machine from thingiverse. The print took a total of 24hrs. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45347 Here is a link to some videos and more pictures on the build.
http://helpme3dprint.com/blogs/news/19779651-3d-printed-gumball-machine-repaired-using-wood-filler Everything printed correctly until the final minutes. The top layer was not thick enough and holes materialized. For months the printed model sat idle. Then a few days ago I realized that wood filler might be the key to salvaging this print. After a few coats of wood filler and some paint the final result is smooth and looks great. After assembly I realized that the machines hopper was too large. I modeled an insert which is in two pieces. You will need to crazy glue them together after they are printed. Hold them in the position that you would like and run crazy glue along the seams. Wipe any access off and hold it together while it drys.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online. These are parts for an Operation "brain-themed" game using open and closed circuits. https://www.tinkercad.com/things/06EFxStJlde

print_settings.Notes:: Alternatively, you can choose to print it standing on its rear end, but since that's not flat you'll need a bit of support structure underneath to provide the necessary adhesion to the bed for stability. I haven't tried this approach though, but it should also work out.

description.text:
An easy to use and fully reusable female urination device that enables women to pee standing up, thus giving them more freedom and options to relieve themselves. No more squatting over a dirty public toilet or sacrificing your dignity behind the bushes. Bring your peeing skills up to the next level and pee anywhere a man could pee :)

This design has been battle-tested by my girlfriend a few female friends. Their feedback was overwhelmingly positive and unanimous: it truly works! And what's better, they all used it successfully on their very first attempt, which instantly boosted their confidence and removed any fears of ending up with wet pants. They also praised how hygienic this method was. Nonetheless practice always makes perfection, so you may want to try it first a few times in the shower or in your bathroom.

Any feedback or ideas on how to improve the design further are definitely welcome!

Printer:

XYZ DaVinci 1.0 (modded)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

This model can be printed without any support structures by positioning it to stand on its small and flat end. It's advised to configure the slicer software to also print a wide and possibly 2 layers high skirt around it with no separation from the body of the model. This will greatly increase the adhesion of the model to the print bed. You can easily remove/detach this skirt of the model once the print is finished. There are 2 pictures showing this technique.

The downside of this approach is that the other end of the model, the rear part, becomes then an overhang, which most printers may have trouble with. You can see in my pictures of the finished print how that area shows some visible filament strings. However you can easily remove the few that might be left hanging without affecting the functionality of the device. It's just a cosmetic issue.

Alternatively, you can choose to print it standing on its rear end, but since that's not flat you'll need a bit of support structure underneath to provide the necessary adhesion to the bed for stability. I haven't tried this approach though, but it should also work out.

No post-processing should be necessary on this model, unless you wanna smooth out the edges a bit.

Here is a pro-tip though: Optionally use one of those anti-rain sprays to give the device a coating of water-repellent that will greatly reduce the remaining amount of urine that stays on the plastic after using it.

Initially I printed and tested (or rather, had my girlfriend test!) the two other existing FUD designs in thingieverse at the time of writing this, thing:390127 and thing:320207. Both showed some practical issues and limitations, specially with the inability to handle the urine stream without overflowing. And so it quickly became evident that I should create something better.

So I set out to design a model with the following requirements:

  • Easy and intuitive to use: Just unzip or unbutton your pants and pee with peace of mind. It shouldn't require to be positioned exactly right or to create a tight seal against your body for it to work successfully.
  • Should be able to handle as much as you can pee on it without overflowing.
  • Easy to clean and reuse: A bit of water to rinse it and a paper tissue or similar to dry it should be all you need to leave the device ready for further use.
  • Printable without support structures.

I dusted off my rusty SketchUp skills and a couple hours later I came up with the first version (see model v1 in the Files tab), which turned out to work pretty well, actually. It pretty much met all the requirements and the 'tester' was quite satisfied with it, but the engineer in me couldn't let it settle without at least one round of improvements. So the second revision came to life with a slimmer rear end and with an improved shape to create a better seal with the body, while the funnel was also more curved downwards to give it a more appropriate angle. Once again the 'QA team' signed off on the improved design, and so this is what ended up as the v2 model available in the Files tab.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/dTBfic5Nep0

Now we have walls for the OpenForge 2.0 port of ruined stone. I've tried to make these much more organic and jumbled then my normal wall tiles. For every length of wall, I've produced full height, half height and low, which is just a few stones slightly above the line of the floor tiles. For the 2x walls, I have also produced transitions so we have form low -> full, full -> low and every other combination.

I've also included floors cut for this, including every size and current variation (2x2.a -> 2x2.i). I made this a construction kit rather then a solid tile, because the possible combinations here are extremely large. So print out a base, pick a floor tile and a wall and then glue.

There's a separate thing for OpenLOCK and OpenLOCK + magnetic bases for these tiles.

When you glue a base to the wall, one corner has two stones instead of one. That corner matches to the wall to give a smoother connection, as that one side has a combination of the texture of the rough stone base and of the ruined walls.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. description.text: SIMBOLO CAPRICORNIO
playing with blendshapes

This was my first Request by a co-worker at my organization to design an object from scratch to solve a specific real world issue. My Network Admin came to me with the issue that in some areas of our Building the Cisco switches had to be mounted vertically as opposed to the normal horizontal rack mount. The issue was that he only had 1-2 fiber channel ports in use and the other Mini-GBIC ports were empty and being mounted vertically meant that dust and dirt were getting into the open ports and getting into the Routers. He wanted to know if I could design a Plug/Cover for the unused Mini-GBIC Ports. Two iterations later (first one the pull tab was too thin and flimsy) I was printing them out for him in Dozens to deploy around the Building.... SUCCESS!!

Since my search had come up dry when I first looked to see if someone had already designed such an Item, I wanted to Share my Model for the next person looking for this item and not have to design something themselves. I think that my model could be improved to cut a groove around the top to hold a rubber o-ring to truly seal the port, but for our vertical mount switches, Gravity does all the work.

Please let me know if anyone else prints these. I'm curious to see if this item is helpful to others.

Cheers!

description.text:
OpenLOCK and OpenLOCK + magnet bases for the ruined wall set. I've started including all 16 sizes, even though OpenLOCK doesn't necessarily have letters for all of them. Where it matches an OpenLOCK size, it has the letter for it.

Filename key:

  • openlock: these have the openlock ports.
  • magnetic.openlock: these have holes for magnets and they have openlock ports, with magnets getting priority where they conflict (1x and x1 tiles on the short edge)
  • openlock.magnetic: same as magnetic.openlock, but giving priority to openlock. I've only included the 7 tiles where this makes a difference.

When you glue these to the wall, one corner has two stones instead of one. That corner matches to the wall to give a smoother connection, as that one side has a combination of the texture of the rough stone base and of the ruined walls.

After encountering serious wobble in the X beam of my TronXY X1, I thought I might need something akin to the bed tightener by PB2000 ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2203872 ). However, this piece is designed to work on on 2020 openbuild V-Slot following the documentation ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:69333 ), and the Z-Axis of the TronXY X1 is made from a 2040. So, spacing couldn't be taken over.

The Version 0 test type took the measurements of Press Reset's brackets ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2120675 ), but the spacing of the print was off. WAY off. I had to cut it up, using them as spacers to be screwed on. Back to field 1: start from scratch, grab the documentation.

Taking the measurements of the metal piece, the openbuilds documentation (measurements of the V-Slot beam and matching 23.9mm wheels), the ISO norms (M4 & M5 machine screws), I startet to design the piece from scratch with set goals in mind:

  • the bend should leave space for the M4 screw that holds the actual X-Beam on the TronXY X1
  • it should act as spacer just as much as tightener
  • two pieces shall clamp it in position around the 2040 beam

After dissembly to check the measurements, I noticed that the wobble did not originate in a lack of tightening, but my failure: a single screw was not pulled tight enough.

5 Versions are available:

  • 75% plastic thread - this variant is designed to carry a thread for M5 cut into it and has holes of 4.2 mm diameter. The part will act like connected nuts, keep this in mind in assembly, like when you want to clamp the beam between two!
  • Close Fit - This variant is meant to leave no wriggle for the screws, but it does not bite down on them either. 5.25 mm diameter holes.
  • Standard Fit - somewhat more loose, this is the diameter of the holes in the metal plate I took the original measurements from.
  • 75% plastic thread and Standard fit on the two back holes with a hole to hold the 7.11mm cylinder of an Openbuild eccentric nut, allowing adjustment of the tightener

EDIT:
After encountering, that the walls of the threaded variant can bend a bit while cutting the thread, all variants were updated with thicker walls.

Version 0 with length estimations based on PressReset's X-plate. It ended up having to be cut apart, acting as screw on spacers First Draft - avoiding the M4 screw that holds the X-Axis like this would have forced the bend to end inside the X-Axis stepper. => Discarded Side View of Iteration 1 - notice that the measurements here are off by 0.4mm in Z and XZ! Itteration 2: Avoiding the M4 screw head on the other side seemed like a better idea, yet still the measurements were off Iteration 3 - Loose Fit Variant: After reconfirming all the measurements, the redesign of the piece was just a matter of drawing the pieces. complete assembly plan, as found in the TronXY X1 - Pink: Acrylic plate; Not shown: Steel back plate.

title: Turn your ammunition box into a storage box

description.text:
Old ammunition boxes are great for all hobby purposes like fishing, camping and so on. They are water and dust tight, cheap and durable.
I've created this box to store small parts like fishing gear, spare parts for model aircrafts, cars or any other outdoor product.
It fits nicely into an standard ammo box (cal. 300x7.62 or 840/930x5.56 or 100x.50) and it has 3 big compartments for big tools and parts and 5 drawers of different sizes for all those easy-to-lose parts. 3 of those drawers are dividable by a divider.
A latch stops the drawers from opening.

Also this box contains of over 40 parts, the assembly is quite easy. Build the basic box and then the drawers, the order should be pretty clear. Edit: I've uploaded two images of both sheets with some comments. Just a brief assembly instruction:
  • Assemble handle with divider handle/back (The notch in the handle piece belongs into the drawer back)
  • Add the bottom and the drawer bottoms (all drawer bottoms are identical)
  • Add both sides to the construct
  • Sort the drawers by their size/height and assemble them. All drawer bottoms (the real ones, not the in-between parts you've assembled before) are the same. 3 big ones and 2 small ones.
  • stick the handles to the drawers.
  • ????
  • profit!

title: Malyan M150 Y Axis idler upgrade and belt tensioner

description.text:
This is my Y-axis upgrade for Malyan M150 with original belt.
The original belt idler and tensioner is free to move and rotate so I redesigned it to make the Y-axis more rigid and easier to adjust for belt tension.
Attention: you have to drill 2 new holes in the front frame. Do at your own risk. Measure carefully before drill.

This idler uses more common F624 bearing (also normal 624zz are suitable).
I printed all the parts in nGen but also PLA should works at 0.2mm, 100%infill, 2 perimeter

Print items the in the orientation they drop in a slicer.
NO SUPPORTS NEEDED!

Youl will need:
x2 Bearings F624 (or 624zz)
x2 M3 nut
x1 M3x30 screw
x1 M6x30 (or 40) comon wrench bolt (corrected)
x2 M4x15
x1 M4x25
x3 M4 nuts
x2 M4 washer (optional, only if the bearing are loose)

The knob you see in the photo, used to tension the belt is from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1862226

I created this bracket to enable the use of higher quality case bearings on my FlashForge Creator Dual (Replicator 1 Dual).  The case bearings for the Y-axis motion transfer rods are flanged (5mmx10mmx4mm) bearings that are pretty low quality.  
I decided to use ceramic bearings for my pillow blocks (5mmx11mmx4mm) but couldn't find any flanged bearings that were ceramic!  So I bought flangeless bearings of the correct size (5mmx10mm4mm) and used these brackets to hold them in the correct position in the case.  The positioning of these bearings in the case is important so the pulleys line up correctly with the gantry mounting locations.  
Word to the wise, when you drill through your case, use a small drill bit first and then a larger one at high speed so you don't damage your ply-wood.  You can also try to butt up a piece of wood on the inside of the drilled area and it will stop any splintering.  
Design modeled in Pro/E by Patrick C.

Printed with PLA and 40% infill.  Use M3 screws a couple washers and a nylon lock screw to attach to your case.  You could use very small wood screws also.  There really isn't any force against these brackets, they are just here to make sure the flangeless bearing doesn't wiggle out!

Hobbing Tool i made for using with a proxxon KT 70 micro compound table (or similar) and a drill press.

• print
  • add bearings
  • add hobbing tool to the compound table
  • mark where you want to roughen the bolt
  • add the bolt
  • insert a thread tap into the drill press
  • start the drill
  • move the bolt to the thread tap by using the compound table

comments.text: It is very easy to make a bolt using this tool.  I used a M5 tap and cut (pushed the tap into the side of the bolt) 0.038".  The process takes about 5 min per bolt.

TrussFab Bottle Table is made of 48 bottles and 10 3D printed connector hubs.

TrussFab is an integrated end-to-end system that allows users to fabricate large scale structures that are sturdy enough to carry human weight. TrussFab achieves the large scale by complementing 3D print with plastic bottles. It does not use these bottles as “bricks” though, but as beams that form structurally sound node-link structures, also known as trusses, allowing it to handle the forces resulting from scale and load. TrussFab embodies the required engineering knowledge, allowing non-engineers to design such structures and to validate their design using integrated structural analysis. We have used TrussFab to design and fabricate tables and chairs, a 2.5 m long bridge strong enough to carry a human, a functional boat that seats two, and a 5 m diameter dome.

You can also find out more about the project here: https://hpi.de/en/baudisch/projects/trussfab.html

hints for assembly

The table is originally built from 1l bottles which are combined by their bottom with tape or screw. You can use any bottle size/type, as long as they are all the same in the model. If you use soft bottles, you can also inflate them to achieve better stability. In this case their bottom needs to be taped together, not screwd. According the type of the bottle you are using you will need the corresponding connecting cuffs (refillable/non-refillable). These are the most common bottle types, but in case you want to use some other type you can design your own connector cuffs for that.

Model in SolidWorks
Cam mount for the Smartshapes Rush. Print this at 20mm/s.
This is a 4 inch by 4 inch box. It was made to be placed on a desk so it can hold things.

To start, I got the box template PDF online. I then went on Adobe Illustrator and deleted the top side. On all of the sides except for the bottom I flatten their tops. I then live traced each of my pictures on place one on each side including the bottom. I printed out the box using acrylic and the Epilog Laser. The raster settings were speed 100 and power 60. The vector settings were speed 10, 100 power, and 5000 frequency. I assembled the box using acrylic glue.

print_settings.Notes:: I've chosen 100% infill to make it stronger.

author: beyondallgaming

description.text:
TrussFab Bottle Chair is made of 36 recycled refillable bottles and 8 3D printed connector hubs.

TrussFab is an integrated end-to-end system that allows users to fabricate large scale structures that are sturdy enough to carry human weight. TrussFab achieves the large scale by complementing 3D print with plastic bottles. It does not use these bottles as “bricks” though, but as beams that form structurally sound node-link structures, also known as trusses, allowing it to handle the forces resulting from scale and load. TrussFab embodies the required engineering knowledge, allowing non-engineers to design such structures and to validate their design using integrated structural analysis. We have used TrussFab to design and fabricate tables and chairs, a 2.5 m long bridge strong enough to carry a human, a functional boat that seats two, and a 5 m diameter dome.

You can also find out more about the project here: https://hpi.de/en/baudisch/projects/trussfab.html

hints for assembly

The chair is built from the combination of 0.5l and 1l bottles which are combined by their bottom with tape or screw. The individual bottle size is not very important but the ratio between the small and a big bottles should be roughly 1:1.3. If you use soft bottles, you can inflate them to achieve better stability. In this case their bottom needs to be taped together, not screwd. According the type of the bottle you are using you will need the corresponding connecting cuffs (find in the shop).

description.text: Here's the newest version of my design I based this one of a necklace my brother had

Homemade flying base for my nightscythe.

V1 has a little base, V2 has a larger one.

This is the filament spool we are using on our AO-100 MendelMax variant printer. The spool mount takes the place of one of the top vertex frame parts. You will also need a length of tubing to guide the plastic to the hot end. The tubing is attached to the feed tube support with a small zip tie. The spool is meant to hold an unspooled 5lb coil of filament. The spool mount can also be used to mount a spool of plastic using a threaded rod and spool hubs. Source files can be found at http://download.lulzbot.com/AO-100/hardware/printed_parts/source/ Update New revision of the spool mount which now includes a break to keep the spool from over spinning. Use a M4 screw to mount the friction nub. Licensing
-Parts and files: GPLv3
-Images: CC BY SA

Print the following quantity of parts: -x1 Hub.STL
-x3 back_arm.STL
-x3 front_arm.STL
-x1 spool_mount_brake.STL
-x1 nub.STL
-x1 Feed_tube_support.STL Required Hardware: -x6 T-slot nuts and M5 screws for the spool mount/vertex and
-x9 M4 20mm Hex head bolt
-x1 M4 20mm SHCS

-x1 M8 50mm Hex head bolt

Belt retainer designed to secure excess webbing on a backpack. This replaces the worn out elastic band that came with the backpack. Fits waist belts 1 1/2" wide.

Once installed, there's a little bit of vertical wiggle room on the retainer, this was by design to allow the retainer to twist a little when used. When putting on the backpack I'd rather not have to worry that the belt retainer is stuck, this helps alleviate that.

The clip will also hold more webbing, in case you need to double it back on itself.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20%

Most of the edges are beveled, but it'll still need a bit of sanding when it's done. I'd recommend 220 grit sandpaper for this. Also, when you remove it from the bed, the clip will be attached to the body, this can easily be broken by pulling, then sanded down for a smooth finish.
Designed in 123D Design, from the grid up.

remixed_from.author: wersy
remixed_from.title: Case for the Full Graphic Smart LCD Controller

title: Reprapdiscount Full Graphic Smart LCD Controller Case

description.text:
I remixed Wersy's LCD case to add a mount to V rails which allows the case to be angled for better viewing from different positions. I also added embossed numbers in the back for the connectors to avoid confusion. Along the way I had to make a number of changes because the Reprapdiscount Full Graphic Smart Controller (sic) seems to have changed - panic button and knob are a bit different. I also changed the "grill" for the beeper as I didn't like the way the holes looked. Not sure mine is better, though! Could probably just eliminate it completely as it's pretty loud to start with. Also, the original front case needed some rework because the lip wasn't deep enough.

You may need to make some changes in the following areas:

  • The original knob was for a D shaft, mine was a press-to-fit one. Depending on how your printer printer does holes, you may need to resize the hole.
  • The panic button on my LCD board stood way too high so I had to rework that. I suspect there are different button switches being used so you may need to mod that. The fit is fairly tight - about 1/2 mm travel on the switch.
  • The V rail mount "fingers" thickness and spacing may need to be tweaked a bit based on your printer,
  • All the holes came out too small for me so I just drilled and/or tapped them.

Be sure to use the spacers (need 4) to prevent shorting the two circuit boards together.

Additional parts needed:

  • reprapdiscount full graphic smart controller+ cables
  • 8 M3x12 screws (edit: I've found that 4-40 1/2" sheet metal screws work great, too)
  • 1 M4x25 screw and nut
  • 2 M5x10 screws and t-nuts for mounting on the rail.

I've included the sketchup file. I imported the original .stl files and used cleanup on them.

Printer:

Makerfarm Pegasus 12

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.25 mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Print one of each part except the spacers, print 4 of those.

Using sketchup to remix stl files

I use the sketchup STL support. Import an STL file and it usually has a lot of polygons, even really simple objects have a lot. The cleanup extension really simplifies the model though - combining co-planar polys into a single face. Once you have done that, it's pretty easy make the changes you want. The image below shows the front of the case being cleaned. To export back to STL, I use the CADSpan STL extension. It seems to produce cleaner STL files than the Sketchup one.

author: DamonP

description.text: For those who dare splint their cat's paw upon injury.

Watch here: https://youtu.be/cv36zcbONoQ

Roberto is finally here! I actually modeled this one a bit ago but I knew it would be very hard to print at a reasonably small scale on my FDM printers. And I knew an SLA printer was heading my way for review, so I waited and it was well worth the wait.

Roberto came out amazing. The supports pulled away extremely easy as long as I was careful to not bend the limbs too far. I actually removed them while wet, using fully gloved hands. There were a few zits where the supports were, but they were minor. The area under the eyes drooped slightly, but that was due to too few supports in that area.

After printing my wife painted it. She hardly needed to sand it, and that right there makes SLA worth it for us. She was able to get to the painting process very quickly compared to the FDM models I give her.

Printer: XYZprinting Nobel 1.0A
Filament: Clear Resin
Layer Height: 0.1mm
Supports: Yes
